Clarification of Referral Question and Record Review
In most settings, the assessment assessment process begins with a discussion (often in an initial phone call or secure electronic exchange) with the patient and/or a referring caregiver or allied health professional, to clarify the identified problem and reason for referral. Clinicians should take special note of words used to define the presenting problem, evidence provided to support the framing of the problem, and the environmental context in which the problem arises. Records can be useful in providing medical or psychiatric history and related medications, as well as documenting prior laboratory tests and previous treatments. Current medical problems and medications should be noted and included in the report. Of note, it is important to maintain a critical stance when reviewing records, being mindful of the potential fallibility of prior evaluations or diagnostic labels, due to reporting biases, variation in clinician interpretation, and the dynamic nature nature of various syndromes (e. g., mild neurocognitive impairment).
Conducting the Clinical Interview
The clinical interview clinical interview should center the patient’s subjective experience and perceived needs for care, while also eliciting sufficient details and chronology to inform a holistic picture of the patient’s presenting problems, as well as approaches to coping. In addition to the general principles described earlier, clinicians should approach the interview with a goal of gathering details about both psychological and physical symptoms, which often requires a sorting out of symptoms to differentiate or identify their overlap. A clinician may find that self-reported symptoms do not correspond with other sources of information. This can particularly particularly arise in the case of concerns about cognitive impairment in that the patient’s perception of their problem may differ from what is present and shown in tests. The chronology of the presenting issues should be assessed and changes such as improvements or worsening should be attended to. As noted, the gathering of information in the interview should also involve obtaining collateral input when available and asking informants about perceived behavioral changes and impacts on the the patient’s functioning and overall quality of life.
Mental Status Exam, Behavioral Observations, and Neurocognitive Screening
Beyond the clinical interview interview , the diagnostic assessment process should also characterize mental status, including mood, affect, appearance, speech, thought process, content, etc. Such details may be derived from the interview content, behavioral observations noted by the clinician, and formal screening measures. Specific aspects of mental status to attend to, particularly if cognitive impairment is suspected, might include: appearance that shows signs of ability to engage in ADLs (e. g., bathing, dressing), speech changes (e. g., dysarthria), thought process being highly circumstantial or showing word finding issues, and thought content being notably concrete. In conjunction with observations and clinical interview, a thorough diagnostic assessment of an older adult should involve the use of a brief cognitive screener. Even for those who may not have obvious signs of cognitive change, it can be useful to conduct yearly cognitive screening to facilitate comparison comparison from baseline to potential future changes. The 3 MS Mini Mental Status Exam (Bravo & Hébert, 1997 ; Jones et al., 2002 ; Teng & Chui, 1987 ) is one reliable and valid screening tool for cognitive impairment. Regardless of the presenting problem, it is also recommended to screen for depression and anxiety symptoms given their prevalence and frequent co-occurrence with other conditions or mimicry of other conditions, particularly in older adults. For example, the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS; Sheikh & Yesavage, 1986 ), Geriatric Anxiety Scale (Segal et al., 2010 ), and the S-MAST substance abuse screening tool (Hirata et al., 2001 ) are all validated with samples of older adults. It is important to consider there is a scarcity of instruments normed on older adults from racial and ethnic minority groups. Providing Feedback and Recommendations
When providing feedback feedback on the assessment findings and related recommendations, one psychoeducational model that is recommended is the “ask-tell-ask” approach. In many cases, it may make sense for both the patient and their family and/or caregiver to be present, particularly if there is implication of cognitive impairment. Even if such impairment is not present, it can be helpful for many patients to have another person available to take notes and hear recommendations, given findings can be emotionally distressing or overwhelming for some. Feedback should maintain a focus on the main findings and communicate these in as clear a manner as possible, avoiding the use of jargon. Any remaining uncertainties regarding the diagnosis or further assessment needed should also be communicated. In both the written report and feedback session, recommendations should be provided that are tailored to the individual, including being feasible for their life circumstances (e. g., supports, resources, living setting), comorbidities if relevant, and current problems. Taking a person-centered approach that also highlights and builds on the patient’s strengths is essential not only to promote self-efficacy and dignity but also to enable the patient to be able to take in aspects of the feedback that may be distressing. To that end, recommendations should align with the patient’s values and model of illness and coping with illness.
